text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria's Supreme Court is expected to rule today on an appeal by First Private Bank against last month's decision by the Bulgarian National Bank to retract its licence.
-- A platoon of Bulgarian engineer corps left for Bosnia to join the United Nations SFOR peace keeping force there. @
-- Bulgaria's state carrier Balkan Airlines plans to replace its old Soviet-made planes before the firm is offered for privatisation, Balkan's executive director Valeri Doganov said.

-- Bulgaria is expected to lift restrictions on buying cash foreign currency by Bulgarians as part of preparations to launch a currency board system from July 1, Bulgarian National Bank governor Svetoslav Gavriiski said. @
At present Bulgarians are allowed to buy cash foreign currency up to the equivalent of $2,000 annually under a government decree.

-- The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) has bought enough German marks on global markets to meet cash demand as part of preparations to launch a currency board system, BNB governor Svetoslav Gavriiski said.
-- Bulgaria's State Railways (BSR) said it would allow private railway companies to use BSR's railway tracks from the beginning of 1998. @
-- Bulgaria's central government budget deficit fell by some 39.18 billion levs in the first half of June to 446.04 billion levs, Finance Ministry figures showed.
-- Bulgaria's State Railways (BSR) said it may choose state United Bulgarian Bank to service company accounts. BSR daily turnover ammounts to some 1.2 billion levs. @

-- Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery Neftochim said it had restructured its board of directors in line with government recommendations to curb losses and tighten administrative control. Neftochim posted some 30 billion levs losses last year.
-- Bulgaria's State Savings Bank, the country's largest savings institution, said it had posted 35.5 billion lev profit for the first five months of this year.
